postContent:
Product management is entering the era of builders. What used to take months is taking days and weeks. What used to take a team of 3 can be done by a single PM. 

AI is changing how we work, and it's redefining what makes a great PM.

1. Builder > Supervisor. Your ability to directly create value now matters more than your org chart position. 

2. New Scoreboard. Revenue per headcount is the metric that matters. When AI compresses cost/time per feature, productivity per person becomes everything.

3. The hierarchy of skills is changing. Judgment at the top, creativity and problem-solving in the middle, execution (increasingly AI-assisted) at the bottom

4. AI makes it easier to build for anyone but amplifies the advantage of knowing what to build, how to distribute, and monetize.

AI is the ultimate leverage multiplier. And we're only at the beginning.

‘PRDs are dead’ is pretty popular thing right now. It is far from truth. I write this as a person who built a free, popular AI prototyping course. 

Here is why - there are two goals of writing a PRD:

1. Thinking long and hard about what you need to build

2. Sharing requirements with others 

#1 is primary goal, #2 is secondary. Writing is a tool for thinking, possibly the best tool for thinking clearly as it eliminates gaps in thinking. And so taken that way, writing a PRD is pretty important. So why is AI prototyping so appealing?

AI prototypes are good for sharing requirements with others in a limited time environment like leadership meetings for buy-in, business, etc. But many things can be lost in translation if engineering or design teams start taking AI prototypes as source of truth. That’s where it becomes unproductive.

postContent:
A PM asked me to explain evals for AI products in simple terms. It’s a pretty popular term and super relevant for PMs. Here is what I shared with her:

Evals are QA testing for AI products. We all are familiar with QA testing since every software company does it. Now the question becomes - why is it coming to PMs rather than setting a dedicated QA team for it?

Here is the reason for it: AI product output is probabilistic whereas software is deterministic. What it means is that software will behave in the same way every time. A button when clicked by 1000s of users will open a modal all thousands of times. But the same prompt used by 1000s of users may provide different responses to different users. That makes testing AI products difficult. It needs to be initially done by someone who understands how AI works, has the context of what users will like or not like, etc. That sort of context is not there with a QA team, so PMs have to do it initially. 

Once the product gets stable and PMs understand the patterns, they can design guidelines on how to test this product. That’s where you set up an evals/ QA team.

Now there are other nuances in the process: like hiring expertise for complex tasks, golden sets, etc. But they can all common sense and be derived for a product as long as you understand that evals is QA and how QA is different for AI vs Software products.

postContent:
Having a single model is one of the best strategic moves by OpenAI this year. And there are three reasons for that:

1. Marginal cost of query can be optimised: This one has been called out by many thought leaders. Marginal cost of query is additional cost of serving another query to the end user. By having a single model (GPT-5), ChatGPT can route simple queries to cheaper models, thereby reducing marginal cost. Earlier, if a user selected a particular model, ChatGPT had to use that much compute. 

2. Simple wins in consumer products: With ChatGPT crossing billions of users, it has to start thinking about the type of user who prefers simplicity over options. This is the late majority on the adoption curve and they don’t want to think much while asking a query. Think Google Search, Tiktok, and WhatsApp where simplicity is an advantage in consumer apps space.

3. Personalisation of queries will create moats: I have been a heavy user of LLMs since the start, partly because a big part of my current role is deep research of products and domains. I also ask the same question using different prompts and go deeper more often than not. Once ChatGPT understands this, it can add a signal in my profile where it activates deep research/ advanced models when I ask a query. The result? I feel it gets my queries and my switching cost increases. Now, replicate the same for a user who prefers simple language responses. ChatGPT writes responses in simple language for the users. With this, we are going to see a level of personalisation never seen before. Let’s call it ‘token level personalisation’. So far, we have seen only fixed entity (shopping item, web page, video, etc) level personalisation. Token level personalisation is going to be at a different level.

postContent:
7 counterintuitive insights from vibe-coding full-stack AI products

Yesterday, I conducted a live session around vibe-coding products. 

Here are 7 counterintuitive lessons from the session you won't hear in most places👇

1. Write The v1 of PRDs manually

From my experience, PMs who remember key metrics without relying on dashboards think more critically and connect data points faster. Apply the same principle to PRDs: draft the first basic version manually to exercise and show product intuition, then refine with AI.

2. AI apps need to manage stakes/ risks in products

In high-stakes domains like education or healthcare, unchecked AI output can mislead users. A safer approach is routing it through experts first—for example, in our EdTech Q&A app, instructors review AI answers before students see them.

3. Bug-fixing skills aren't major win for PMs

Prototypes break when you are building them during the interviews, and the response matters more than the resolution. PMs are judged on problem-solving skills and understanding of tech/ issues, not debugging when it comes to PMs. 

4. Functional prototypes don't equate to production-ready code

When it comes to AI prototypes, the scaling is the easy bit. The core problems are around tech debt, security, compliance, etc. That's why it shouldn't be put in production without proper review.

5. Slow is Fast with LLMs

How do we make sure that the tool like Lovable is just modifying what we told it to and nothing more? The answer is patience. When modifying requirements, we need to first confirm if it understood the changes by asking it to describe the changes. No coding in this step, just chat. Only after that, we should authorise changes.

If you go for speed by doing it all in a single step, it can often result in more time spent fixing bugs.

6. Sequential approach > one-shot

You might develop an urge to put the entire MVP req at one in the tool. But there are two problems with that: First, attempting to build the whole thing increases bugs/failure probability. Second, it's harder to figure out the bugs in a large codebase.
Instead, take a sequential approach: Start at the core functionalities -> Add the AI features -> Build the adjacent layers next, such as authentication layer

7. Have an annual learning budget

"How many tools do we pay for to learn? It’s quite expensive.”

Have a $300-$500 per annum budget for the next two years. The flux is really high in terms of tools and skills. The only way to stay relevant is to master the tools and skills. You can always cancel subscriptions you don’t like. After all, the best investment you can make today is in your skills, body, and mind!

postContent:
With AI, operators in the field have a new problem at hand. What to learn and what to skip?

If you build without learning much, you end up making mistakes and lag behind from some competitor who made the right call. The loop of build and then learn could be expensive.

It you keep learning without building, learning becomes a procrastination tool and counterproductive because there is something new to learn everyday in AI.

I faced the problem myself, and here is what worked  - Start with the problem and work backwards on what to learn!

Step 1: Take a problem, put it in the best LLM model you have access to, and ask for which things you should be learning. 

Step 2: Don’t use LLMs to learn the topics: go to the source and read please. It’s cumbersome but extremely important.

Step 3: Come back to LLMs and use them as a research and thinking tool to build solution.

That’s it. Some of the best people out there are intuitively doing it, but many are making the mistake of being in one of the former categories.

Keep building :)

postContent:
"Build all table stakes, and differentiate on some." Is it a good product strategy? 

On the first level, it looks correct because if you follow it, it will help you differentiate and win.

But real-life product development is messy and there is always competition. Building all table stakes makes you slow, and your product positioning suffers because of it.

Here's what's better:
- Build some table stakes
- Intentionally under-invest in features your segment doesn't value
- Make one/few features absolutely incredible

A user doesn't want everything. They want their biggest pain solved in the best manner. 

That's why even the most comprehensive platforms like Salesforce loses deals to startups like Gong because Gong does one thing better - revenue intelligence.

So how do you fix this? First, it's important to realise that the ambition to do everything comes from the lack of the insight. It can happen on two fronts: who you customer is and who isn't, and what their major pain is. The lack of insight (and answer to both questions) comes from talking to customers.

Talking to customers is a necessary, but not sufficient. There is a good chance they will ask for everything. You have to introspect and see where to focus - this is the core of product strategy. It's good to remember what Jobs said - 

“People think focus means saying yes to the thing you've got to focus on. But that's not what it means at all. It means saying no to the hundred other good ideas that there are. You have to pick carefully. I'm actually as proud of the things we haven't done as the things I have done. Innovation is saying no to 1,000 things.”

postContent:
The consensus on moats is wrong about AI products.

We hear that AI has no moat. And anyone can copy your ChatGPT wrapper.

But here's what they're missing!

Traditional software is deterministic. You can reverse-engineer features and rebuild them exactly. That's why, in the era of software, distribution has been a key moat. 

But what about AI products? They're probabilistic in nature, it's hard to reverse engineer them by looking at output. The final product depends on hundreds of decisions

- How you cleaned your data
- Which edge cases you prioritized
- The specific prompts + policy you refined over months
- The proprietary data/ insights from the user feedback loops
- Latency
- Evals
- Tooling, and many more decisions

And this is where startups like Anthropic beat big-tech benchmarks on coding agents. They made thousands of small decisions that compound into something unique - and it's hard to reverse engineer all of these things by looking from outside. 

The moat isn't the code. It's the speed of iterations, insights, and processes - all of which are tacit and path dependent.  Use all this to build a better product and lock distribution, and by the time others catch up, you will have good moat built around various things.

AI Papers Simplified 

I have been reading papers to understand AI deeply. My brain works better when I take notes and explain while reading a paper. Abstract in simple language: 

"With MCP, the ability to integrate more tools to build complex AI applications is going to increase over time. 

Selecting the right tool for the job is extremely important for building reliable apps/ agents. So we include the info on how to select the right tool in the  prompt of the LLM. Every tool integration requires changes in the master prompt of LLM, and this creates a major problem.

Adding info around more tools can lead to bloating of master prompt. Now, we know from another paper that as prompts get longer, their efficiency (ability of AI to follow instructions precisely) degrades. So while longer prompts can provide more context and improve results, they can also introduce noise and degrade performance. RAG-MCP aims to solve this. 

RAG-MCP is a new kind of architecture (fancy term for system design) proposed in the paper. We offload the task of finding the right tool to RAG. Only the selected tool descriptions are passed to the model, drastically reducing prompt size and simplifying decision-making. 

---

My view is that this is a quite important paper since it makes an agent scalable and efficient. 

I also thought sharing summary notes once in a while will push more PMs/ engineers to read papers. Do let me know how you find it.

postContent:
Apple published 'The Illusion of Thinking' paper in June 2025, and it sparked debates among AI leaders. As a PM reading this paper, here are my top 3 takeaways:

1. The paper focusses tons on the novel evaluation method where they used puzzles like Towers of Hanoi (CS101 problem) with increasing complexity. I have seen PMs asking about how to be best at evals - which is the core job of an AI PM. The research methodology helped me understand how to write evals for a novel situation. So yeah, one way to be the best would be to read these papers.

2. The paper talks about where reasoning LLMs shine, and where they don't. For simpler problems, standard LLMs demonstrate greater efficiency and accuracy. As problem complexity increases, thinking models gain an advantage. However, when problems reach high complexity, both model types experience complete performance collapse. As a PM, it helps me optimise costs of serving a query by routing queries to appropriate model based on their complexities. Better to build a classifier than burn tons of money!

3. It questions the current evaluation benchmark for the reasoning models. From the paper, "We show that state-of-the-art LRMs (e.g., o3-mini, DeepSeek-R1, Claude-3.7-Sonnet-Thinking) still fail to develop generalizable problem-solving capabilities, with accuracy ultimately collapsing to zero beyond certain complexities across different environments". It seems that this is a fundamental limitation, and newer models wouldn't be able to solve it via inference/ compute. So as PMs, whatever projections we are making in complex task resolution due to future model improvements needs to account for this. 

All in all, a pretty refreshing paper. I look forward to more such paper which plays the devil's advocate in the hyped world of AI.

I spent last 3 days talking to customers and became more convinced that using AI for customer research is a stupid move for PMs and companies.  I can articulate three reasons for it.

1. There is no better medium to get feedback from one human than another human. People fill surveys mindlessly. When you call customers, they engage much more of their brainpower. This means better articulation and much more thought through responses.

2. The nuances in data is the key when it comes to building conviction. Doing 1:1 means you can go back and forth on assumptions. What’s more? You have lots of data around tone, facial expressions, and little details. AI can read and summarise text, so by the time you are reading reviews summary, the feedback has lost 90% of signal. 

3. Creative problem solving. This is a point only those who have done good amount of 1:1 conversations with users will understand. When you are listening to customers, your brain goes into creative problem solving mode. You can have ideas and inspiration throughout the process that is hard to come by when reading a report generated by AI.


AI has it’s value. It helped me create scripts, find loopholes or biases in my thinking. But as for core part of research, it fails spectacularly.

postContent:
40% of AI Agent projects will be cancelled by 2027 - Gartner. So how do you avoid that? We recommend this 3 step-process that excellent AI builders use!

Let's first understand the key reasons listed for these project cancellations? High costs and unclear business value!

Most AI projects in organisations right now are in experimental phase. There is also a lot of hype around what AI can and can't do. When it comes to agents, average assistant products are masquerading as AI agents. From the report, "Only about 130 of the thousands of agentic AI vendors are real. Many vendors are engaging in 'agent washing' - the rebranding of products such as AI assistants and chatbots without significant agentic capabilities."

It's an interesting report to come at a time when everyone is promising agents as a magic bullet to solve real business problems. 

What the report doesn't talk about is how to separate what's real from hype. Further, what should you do if you are building an AI agent to avoid this fate. Here are 3 steps I would recommend you to do:

1. Start by looking at independent startups/companies solving the use-case you are going after. For example, suppose you want to build an agent for Sales. Look at the companies already doing something similar (Gong, Salesforce, etc). Take their demos and understand those products. Don't start on a use-case without proper research across India, US, and China markets. If no one is doing what you are thinking, the product feasibility might be low. It's a signal to go deeper into feasibility of the AI use-case. The shortcut to evaluate feasibility is to find a friend or mentor or industry expert who understands AI well, and seek their advice.

2. Create the PRD for this AI MVP once you are convinced about the feasibility. PRDs aren't dead, they are thinking tools for PMs and Founders. Don't listen to anyone who tells you otherwise. List down key risks in this PRD, and how the MVP will help you test those risks. This step is important to ensure you don't have blindspots. And now you are ready to do the 3rd step well. 

3. Create a business plan for the next 2-3 years. This plan would take the API costs, training data, scale, and development + maintenance costs into account. Many a times, you will surprised at how expensive the APIs and data are as compared to your current costs. Make sure you look at gross margins scenarios (adoption based) well, before shipping it to consumers. 

We are in the midst of a major tech shift, and those who understand and master the rules get to reap the benefits during and after the shift.

postContent:
You might have heard the frog in boiling water story: Put a frog in normal water and slowly heat it up. The frog will adjust to each temperature increase until it reaches a point where it can no longer adapt. By then, it's too late to jump out. It's a good metaphor for a lot of situations. I find it relevant for discussions around mid-tier jobs that are going to be impacted by AI.

So why mid-tier? One might ask. 

While everyone is having a general debate around AI replacing jobs, we're missing the nuance around levels which are really at risk. To see that, we can classify every job role in three tiers: fresh graduates, mid-tier, and leadership roles. 

We can see the impact AI already has on fresh graduates hiring. As reported by multiple media sites, CS grads unemployment is at all time high. These graduates are at the early stage of their career, and while the situation is painful, they can see the writing on the wall, and will do something around it in next 1-2 years. My sense is they will become AI-native in next 1-2 years, and start using AI for highest leverage. That will get them back on the track.

Senior professionals with good judgment can delegate to AI effectively. They can act as editors who don't do the main work, but use their judgement to make the output better. They have already been doing it for humans' output for some time. 

But workers with 2-6 years experience? They're the frog in the boiling water. They aren't going to be impacted quickly because they are already in jobs. But here's why they're most vulnerable: they're not senior enough for the complex strategic roles that AI can't handle, yet not junior enough to start fresh. Most importantly, the urgency they feel most around is doing well at current form of jobs, not becoming AI native. The tasks they excel at - analysis, basic coding, content creation, data processing, project management - are exactly what AI does well. 

As to why most can't sense the shift yet, one of my favourite quotes explains that - "the future is already here. It's just unevenly distributed." Look beyond your current role, work on bettering yourself, and your future self will thank you for it!

Day 1/100 — A Tiny Spark, and a Promise to Follow It

This wasn’t the plan.
But something changed after I watched a 2-hour video by Deepak Singh, where he walked through AI agents, n8n, RAG, and workflow design like he was narrating the future.

It wasn’t just informative. It was the kind of content that quietly shifts something inside you. So thank you, Deepak Singh for making it public.

For showing what’s possible.
For reminding me that the best kind of learning… still happens when no one’s watching.

I kept thinking:

How do we design for a world where users aren't the ones clicking every button? Where agents talk to apps, not just people? Where “product” becomes less about interfaces, more about intelligent flow?

I don’t fully know.

But I’ve made myself a promise:

This week, I’ll try building my first basic agent using n8n. And for the next 100 days, I’ll show up here sharing one product insight, one reflection, or one experiment at a time. I will be honest, I was unsuccessful to make an agent what I had envisioned. I did try something and got my hands on dirty. I will approach again with some fresh energy.

This is #Day1 of my #100DaysOfProduct journey.

 
But maybe it’s also Day 1 of thinking differently.

 I want to start small.

Here is the link: https://lnkd.in/gGzvdRqG to the video

Some of my learnings:

AI Agents Are Not Chatbots: Most people confuse agents with just conversational bots. But agents go beyond conversation they can take autonomous actions, trigger workflows, and perform multi-step tasks without direct user input.

n8n + LangChain = No-Code Magic with Depth: Seeing how n8n integrates with APIs, LLMs, and external databases showed me how powerful low-code tools can be especially when paired with frameworks like LangChain for chaining logic and responses.

The Role of RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation): RAG isn’t just technical jargon. It’s how AI systems pull relevant context from external sources (like PDFs, Notion, or internal docs) before responding which radically improves the quality of outputs and user trust.

Future Products Will Be Built on Invisible Interfaces: The most powerful UX might soon be no interface at all. Products will live inside agents, API triggers, and personalized workflows and as PMs/PMMs, we’ll need to think in terms of outcomes, not screens.

postContent:
When I first wanted to buy a computer, I had no clue what to pick. Apart from asking about memory or storage, everything else felt like a mystery. RAM, processor, SSD, HDD — it was a blur of jargon. I didn’t know how it all came together.

Years later, graduating in Computer Science made me fluent in those terminologies. I could throw around terms confidently — servers, APIs, backend, system architecture. But deep down, I often wondered…

Did I really understand tech? Or was I just familiar with the terms? 🤔

Recently, I stumbled upon Tech Simplified by Deepak Singh and it felt like someone distilled my entire degree into 200 pages of clarity. It’s written in a way that even someone with zero tech background can grasp the fundamentals. 

So, here are 10 key insights from the book that stuck with me;

1. Computers don’t “understand” images or text. They process everything as binary — strings of 0s and 1s. Your Spotify playlist, Gmail, even this post — it’s all converted to digital bits.

2. Software is the real driver. Without it , computers are just dumb machines. Software gives instructions and tells hardware what to do — from opening a browser to playing a YouTube video. It’s like your mind guiding your hands.

3. Internet is a physical infrastructure of wires, routers, and servers. When you send a message or stream a movie, your data travels in small packets across continents — like a postal system on steroids.

4. Websites rely on frontend (what you see), backend (logic and storage), and databases (where data lives). A simple login form connects all three in real-time.

5. More Dev Concepts – APIs Are the Middlemen
Ever ordered food via an app? That request went through an API — like a waiter taking your order to the kitchen. APIs help different systems talk to each other without chaos.

6. Mobile Apps – Whether you’re an Android or iOS, mobile apps follow the same logic: input → process → output. But the coding language and frameworks used differ. It’s like writing a novel in Hindi vs English.

7. DevOps – Making Launches Less Scary
DevOps ensures that code goes from developer laptops to real users smoothly. It automates testing, deployment, and monitoring so teams can ship fast without breaking things.

8. System design is like designing a city. You need roads (data flow), traffic lights (load balancers), hospitals (failovers), and everything must work without a crash, even with millions of users.

9. Architecture of popular apps - Ever wondered how Netflix doesn’t crash during peak hours? It’s built with microservices — small independent components that handle different tasks.

10. Working with tech – speak the same language. You don’t need to become an engineer. But knowing the basics helps you empathize and ask the right questions especially as a designer or product leader.

This book helped me to reconnect and relearn lot many things in a simple manner.

P.S: Thanks Karthi for sharing this book.

When Anthropic CEO said that 90% of code will be written by AI in next 6 months, it didn't mean what the world interpreted it to be. 

Yes, 90% of code will be written by AI. But most experienced programmers know the 90-90 rule intuitively

"The first 90 percent of the code accounts for the first 90 percent of the development time. The remaining 10 percent of the code accounts for the other 90 percent of the development time" — Tom Cargill, Bell Labs

It's a humorous, nonetheless accurate take. Bugs/ troubleshooting takes most of the developer's time. So % of code written isn't proportional to % of productivity gains.

I hope founders, especially early-stage, understand this and don't make short-term calls to hurt their companies. 

In a world where writing code becomes a commodity, you still have to find the scarce resource to use it as a competitive advantage. It could be quality software or more features. But it's not going to be optimising costs.

My entire life has been a series of kind mentors guiding me throughout. If I had to pass one advice on picking mentors, it would be this: Always notice how you feel after talking to a mentor. 

If you feel energised and excited to take action after you have chatted with this mentor, you have found a terrific one. If you feel down after the conversation (however short it was), stay away from such people in future.

Based on my experience, not all mentorship advice makes a difference. Know that there is no secret sauce that a mentor can give you. But the mentors who eventually make a difference will do so by helping you at difficult times in your life. They will do so engaging with you long-term because they love seeing someone excel due to their inputs. 

If you are looking hard enough, you will have some bad luck but you will find a good mentor along the way. Such people rarely judge you. They can be blunt but it will not feel like a bad thing because there is care and goodwill involved. It's the same thing as a close friend being blunt with you. They will be able to show potential/skills that you didn't even realise you had. 

The most common trap to avoid is looking at someone's credentials, and taking those credentials as a proxy for good mentor. We need to understand that best performers, whether in sports or life, aren't best captains/ coaches. So don't make this mistake of adhering to someone's mentorship just because they have done exceptional in their career. 

Finally, pick someone who has been where you want to go. Don't pick executive coaches who haven't been in executive roles. Don't seek advice on startups from a mature company PM. The list goes on.

Here is to finding a good mentor and the blessing they are 🥂
